title: The Impacts of Parental Behaviour on Birth Weight
abstractText:
Although there is still much to learn about early childhood development, the evidence so far suggests that allocations of parents' time and goods to children have important effects on their early development and long-lasting effects on their adult outcomes. 

One indicator of early childhood development is birth weight, which affects brain growth and infant health and has been found to impact educational attainment, earnings, adult height and health.   

This study proposes to assess to what extent parental inputs, such as age of the mother at birth, birth order, interval between births, mother’s smoking and health, directly affect birth weight. It also aims to investigate how these inputs vary with important characteristics of the family, such as the presence of a partner, household income, and the mother’s share of the latter.

The empirical evidence will be provided by the British Household Panel Survey. This survey collects birth weight for all children born during the period 1991-2004 and provides measures of time-varying maternal inputs and other household attributes. Crucially, the survey offers information on women who have had at least two births making it possible to control for time-invariant unobserved characteristics of the mother which might be correlated with the observed inputs.
